text:
Maybe I'll start with
a little background. I'm must say, I was
reluctant to do this

only because 50
years is a long time. And I think that the world
was so different 50 years ago.

And I really wonder
if students will get much out of what happened. But there's some things
I think I did well

and some things I think
I could have done better. And so I'll try to
highlight some of those. I'll start with my family.

I won't spend a
lot of time on this but I think I'm probably the
luckiest person in the world, in terms of the
parents that I had.

My dad was the 15th
of 16 children. He only went to the fifth grade. And he moved from Montgomery,
Alabama to Detroit, Michigan

to find a job in a factory. And he made a round of all the
auto plants at the age of 13. And back in those days you had
to be 18 to work in the plant.

He didn't get a full time job
until he was 16 years old. And went to work at
Chrysler from the age of 16,

retired at 59, and think about-- in fact I was a
college student, I got him to retire because I went
through retirement formula--

and imagine not
being 60 years old but you have 43
years in one place. But where my dad was fascinating
is he was very, very smart.

And I knew many of the men
he worked with in the plant, he's the only one
had a child who went to college, the only one.

My mother wanted
to go to college. Her dad would not let her go. He thought it was a
waste of money for women. So she taught me to read
and write before I ever

started kindergarten. And I started kindergarten,
I could read really well. I could write cursive,
couldn't print

which they thought was odd. But my mother would ask me every
day, for the first four or five days, what did you learn? And she didn't like
what she heard,

so she came and took
me out of public school and the next day put me
into Catholic schools. And so I had a great
education from the start.

It was always assumed
I'd go to college. And my dad always said, the key
to a better life in this world is through education.

So back when I was
thinking about college, the Russians had put up a
satellite called Sputnik.

And there was a big
cry for engineers. And I said, OK, I
didn't know what to do. I said, I'll be an engineer.

So I went to Wayne State. I got a BS in
electrical engineering. And there weren't many
African-Americans. It was one in the
electrical engineering,

I was the only one, one
in chemical engineering, we were the only two. When I graduated, I
had the scholarship

from Detroit Edison, I'd
worked for Pontiac motors. But I didn't want to do-- I didn't like the work. But I couldn't figure
out what else to do.

And so I did the
most illogical thing, I ended up at Cornell
in a PhD program. And I was funded by NASA.

I was doing research for NASA. And I would say I was maybe
23, maybe, or maybe 24.

And it dawned on me,
you know, I could have a 30 or 40 year
working career in something that I really don't want to do.

But I knew I liked business, so
I applied to HBS and I got in. And I absolutely loved it.

And it was difficult
for me to tell my dad that I was going to come
here, because his view was

that all business was
done in the country clubs, and on the golf courses and
that I would be excluded because I was African-American.

And when I did finally tell
him I was going to come, he said, well you know I
only went to the fifth grade so I don't know. He said, but John
Kennedy went to Harvard,

so I know it's a good school
and I know that you'll work. And I graduated.

I went to work for McKinsey,
which I absolutely loved. But you know, again,
not a great place where you want to start a family.

So my wife I wanted
to start a family, I left and went to
work for Citibank. And I was chief of staff
for Walter Wristan and Bill

Spencer, who were president
and chairman of the bank. And I went through
a period where I was at the highest level
staff job the bank had.

And there was not a
great next job for me. So I talked to Walter Wristan
about what do I do next.

And then he said, well
what do you want to do? I said, I'd like to get
into the mainstream of what the bank does, which
was corporate finance.

And in his response, well, what
do you need to know to do that? I said, well the one
thing HBS, I thought,

did not do well-- as was
it could of done-- was teach accounting. So I was taken out of that job
and I went into an accounting

course with all these young
MBA's and that's where I truly learned accounting. And then I was put into
a department lending

to the broadcast and
cable TV industry. And that's where my love
of corporate finance came. I then did that for
a number of years.

And I got approached
to become treasurer of Ally corporation, which
was in Morristown, New Jersey. But we decided,
they said, we'd like

you to go to our oil
and gas subsidiary and it was the largest
independent oil and gas

subsidiary in the US. I went, I was
treasurer for a year.

And then my boss,
who was the CFO said, I'd like you to take
the comptroller's job.

And I said I absolutely
don't want that job. I said, I think the
work's not interesting. I don't think the
people's interesting.

I don't think it's
something I want to do. Now, I would say that
the one great thing that was with me through my whole
career is I loved what I did.

And when you love the work you
do, you will do a better job and you'll be much more
strategic at what you do.

And he kept pressing me and
I wouldn't agree to that job.

So finally the CEO of the
company called me and he said, Bob, he said, you
are not promotable unless you do that job. He said, I'm going to put you
in whether you want to do it

or not. So I came home, my wife
and I talked about it. And she always worried about me. She always worried that I was
going to be badly treated.

And she said, you're the
only African-American in senior management, I
think you should quit. I think you should
find another job. And I said, well let me try it.

I'll see. It turned out to
be a fantastic job. And I learned I could not
have done virtually anything

that I did after that,
without having done that job. I participated in class
today, Professor Foley's class

about CFO. And I talked to them about how
being treasurer or controller is a typical route into that.

And students today
think about that. Back then, all I was thinking
about I was I loved what I did.

So I did that job for a year. Then, I was promoted to CFO
of the oil and gas subsidiary.

And I had done that for a year. Well now, they decided they
want to sell the company. Well then the deal
was structured

and they said will
you stay behind. In fact, I was in
I was negotiating to move to Morristown, New
Jersey to become treasurer

of Ally corporation. And they said, will
you stay behind to help us structure a sale? And the sale we
structured was to KKR.

They bought half of the company. And so I had the opportunity,
I spent probably six weeks

in KKR's office in San Francisco
preparing the operating memorandum. And every day I'd have
lunch with the KKR team

and they would go
around the table. And we'd all opine on the deals
and I was sworn to secrecy. I learned an awful lot.

I got to know George, Henry,
Jerry, all three of the KK and the R. And it was
an unbelievable learning

experience. Well then after we'd
done that, the issue became how do you finance
the leveraged buyout.

And George said I want
Banker's Trust to do this deal. They don't exist today but
they were a big bank back then.

And I said, Banker's
Trust can't do your deal because you need to
have your own petroleum

engineers on staff to
put together a syndicate. I said, they've had a
couple of bad deals. They've laid off their
petroleum engineers.

There's no way they can
do this deal for you. George said, I don't
agree with that. He said, but you try
who you think will do it

and I'm going to get
Banker's to do it. Well it turned out, Banker's
Trust wouldn't do it. And I got J.P.
Morgan to do a deal.

George then said,
will you stay behind to become an equity investor
in the leveraged buyout. And I said sure. And I thought my wife was
dying to leave Houston.

She didn't like it. And I said, well, we'll
just be here two years. And I viewed it as
very much a financial--

I thought I'd do well
financially having done it. Well, we went out we did a
massive road show in the US,

then we took the
Concorde to Europe and did a road show
all over Europe. We had stops in Asia.

We put together the deal. It closed. Oil prices were
almost $30 a barrel. And experts were saying,
yeah, we'll get to $100.

Well in nine months we were
selling oil at less than $10 a barrel. We laid off a third
of the workforce.

And what I thought would
be two years turned out to be eight years. It was the most incredible
learning experience--

we went to selling assets. We went to making the
company more efficient.

We ended up doing an
initial public offering. It was eight years of
incredible learning.

And throughout all of this,
what I think I did really well was I loved doing it and
did a good job of it.

What I didn't do so well,
is I didn't see the benefit of all the things that I did. I think Jonathan mentioned that
Bill George was the one that

recommend-- and I've
never had anyone ask me about what I did
during the leveraged buyout. And I remember when
I met Bill George.

Bill sat down and he knew that
he wanted to grow Medtronic. And he said tell me
what you've done as CFO.

And I started walking, I don't
have a resume or anything, let me just do
this year by year. And I got maybe a third of
the way through and Bill said,

that's more than I've heard
from any one I've talked to. And so discussions
kind of went along,

and I wasn't really
wanting to join Medtronic. And I wanted to take a couple
of years, because, you know, they were at a point
where KKR wanted

to begin again to sell the
assets and kind of wind the company down. And I said I think I'll take two
years and just not do anything.

So I talked to Bill and he tried
to interest me in Medtronic. And I wasn't quite buying
it and he said, well,

why don't you spend a couple
of days with the Medtronic rep. And the Medtronic rep you
think as a salesperson but they really are-- they
are on call 24 hours a day.

[INAUDIBLE] For two days I went
to the operating room and I would stand as close
to the patient, literally two

or three feet away. And I'd scrub down
and I really began to kind of like the business
but still wasn't quite sure

I wanted to do it. Then we had KKR and
Ally, we had done

each of them we had done
put in the public offering each were down to 38% ownership.

Ally wanted to sell theirs,
KKR want to stay in. So I worked with Goldman
Sachs and I structured a deal where Ally could sell
theirs if KKR would

agree to a two-year standstill. So then, to do that, they needed
me to stay as CFO to basically

do another road show. And so I withdrew from
consideration for Medtronic. And then Bill George
came back and said, well, we haven't made
an offer but we're

kind of moving in that direction
and if you're interested, we'll just stop the search
for a couple of months, let you do what you want to
do and then we'll pick it up.

And I'd say that, more
than anything else, said something about
the kind of company that Medtronic was and
helped push me along.

But I won't drag you
through all the things that I did in my eight years
but I knew every investment bank on the street.

I knew every commercial bank. I worked with the
rating agencies. I've done public offerings.

I've done debt deals. I've done equity. It was just such an
incredible range of things, but I didn't really
recognize the value of it

until at a later point. So that's kind of
an introduction. I don't know if you'd like to
take questions at this point.

Yeah, so just as a reminder to
the folks that are joining us by the web, you can email your
questions into aasu@hbs.edu

and we'll be sure to circulate
those questions then to Bob. And I would just say that some
of the things that I learned,

I think that you don't want to
shy away from tough businesses or businesses that have
tremendous challenge

because when that is the
case, number one, that's a great learning experience. And number two, it
causes the people

who run the organization
to focus on people who can get a job done. Because you don't
have the luxury

of putting in someone who's
not going to do the right job. And I think you-- and I don't want to say
racism doesn't exist I'd

have to be stupid to say that. It does exist, but you
do have to understand that people work at what's
in their best interest.

And if you're going to do a road
show that's all over the world, and you're trying to
place a couple of billion worth of assets you've got
to come with who you think

is going to get that job done. And I can remember when I moved
into the comptroller's job, beginning in Texas, my thought
was hey, the guy's in this job

is an accountant. I'm not a professional
accountant. I'm not interested in it. But I brought a very
different perspective.

And I was so well accepted by
the people in the organization, as well as management.

So, again, I think
don't shy away from difficult circumstances. That's going to be a
learning experience

and I think you're more
likely to be treated well. I would also say
that what you learn, and this is what I talked to
the students about this morning.

If you want to be CFO, now in
today's world, young people like yourselves, you can think
about how to become a CFO

and what are the things I
need to know to get there. I did virtually
all the things you need to do to be a good CFO,
but not knowing at the time.

And I did them because
they had to be done. But I think, young
people today, you can begin to think about that.

And you can begin to
think about how you position yourself to do that. The other thing that I've told
a lot of African-Americans

is you need to try
to find a mentor in an organization, someone
that can give you good advice.

And by good advice, I
mean not just good advice, but also good criticism. Somebody who cares about you and
about you in the organization

and will tell you what
you don't do so well. So you can do that better. And I would tell
you one anecdote.

I came to Medtronic,
maybe 20 years ago. I came here to HBS to
recruit for Medtronic.

And I recruited a guy
named Chris O'Connell, who ended up coming. He was one of two
or three people I identified that
I wanted to hire.

And Chris now runs
the Water Company, which is a company
here in Massachusetts. I'll never forget, he came in
to see me one day and he said,

Bob said you're much the
reason I came to this company. And I consider you
to be my mentor. And I didn't get it
until he walked out.

He didn't say will you be he
said, I consider you to be. And it was as if he
had handed me something and I accepted what he
handed me without realizing

that I had accepted. And I began to think
differently about him because I had a position
of investor relations that I wanted and I ended up
coming back to him for that.

So my point being, you
need to think about that. And I think you
need to find people

who will care enough about
you to be critical of you.

So maybe, I rattled
on a bit, maybe now we'll see what
questions I can answer.

Yes? So you said that
management wants to put people in places that
know how to get things done.

So how did they
know that about you? Because it sounds like
fairly early on you were forced to be in control
or you were given these roles,

how did that happen? What did they see in you? You know, I think
they have to look at how you deal with things,
how you deal with people,

how you deal with the issues. And I give an example. When I was in Texas and we get
the initial public offering,

I mean, every single
year we had a crisis. And when we decided to do the
initial public offering this

was really it was what they
called Black Monday, which happened in 1987.

This was when the
stock market crashed. And we had back in that time,
KKR and myself and Allied,

we sat down and interviewed
all the investment banks. And we were absolutely
convinced that the stock was going to go out at $26 a share.

And so we put
together a road show. We did a massive road
show here in the US.

Then, First Boston was
our investment banker. They don't even exist today.

And we took the
Concorde to Europe and did a massive
road show in Europe. Then took it back to
the US, basically,

for the very last day. The eight or nine
or ten days that we were in Europe the market got
worse and worse and worse.

And what we thought wouldn't
be a $26 deal got down at $14. And we sat down at
the end of the day

and Allied and KKR
were both going to sell some of their shares. And they said this
is a price that we don't want to sell our stock.

We think it's worth
more than that. But we decided to put stock out
at that value to reduce debt.

And George Roberts used to have
a saying, if the money holds luck will follow. And what George was
saying was let's

make sure the company exists. And if we have to take a deal
that's not an optimal deal, let's take it to survive.

And so we did that. So after we closed the deal,
I got a call the very next day

And I had no idea
what specialists did. I knew nothing about them. And I did a little
bit of reading and I called Marcus
Schloss and I

said I want to come and
spend a week with you. And I sat on the floor of the
stock exchange for a week. And that's how I
learned all about what

the stock exchange does. Well then you-- and I'm
answering your question in a long winded
way to say, that I

think they were looking at the
way I did things and the way I got things done. Then you fast forward
a lot of years

later when Bill George wanted
me to come to Medtronic, well Medtronic is a company
that had more cash than debt. They had not much in the
way of bank relationships.

They didn't have much
in the way investment banking relationships. And I actually introduced
George to Hank Paulson who was in my Business School
class, who, at the time,

with the CEO of Goldman. And then Bill went on to
become a director of Goldman.

And so the first thing
I said to Medtronic when

I joined, if you've
got plans to grow, you never know when
and where you're going to have to raise money.

When you're a
global company, you want to have equity
investors all over the world. We had no equity
investors outside the US.

And so I said, what we need to
do is every year, once a year, do a road show. We can go out and the
time to acquaint people

with your company is when
you don't need money. So when you do need money,
then they are there to know. And I remember coming
into the company

and the Head of
Investor Relations was a guy named Dale
[? Beamer. ?] Dale said, you know I've been in
this job for x years

and I don't want
to do it anymore. And I said, well you don't
know what changes we're making. And so we then went to Europe.

I remember the first year
that we went to Europe. I remember we had a meeting
at the Bristol hotel in Paris.

There were like, less
than a dozen people there nobody knew a pacemaker
from a defibrillator. They didn't know anything
about the company at all.

We did that every year
for four or five years. And when finally, Medtronic
needed money, we went back, there were 200 people.

And much of our equity
was raised outside the US. So again, I think they just
look at how you do things.

And they look at, you
can be a finance person, and I said this to
students earlier today, who knows what the rules are.

But you also, the way the
world of finance moves is you partner with business and
you help them get things done.

But get things
done the right way.  Yes?

You mentioned the importance
of having a mentor that would give you good
advice and criticism, can you talk about your most
memorable advice and criticisms

you've received from mentors
throughout your career? Well I can tell you, when
I first joined McKinsey,

you'd be on a team. And I was the only
African-American that would be out to
meet with a client.

And you could just tell that
they wanted to know, well, why are you here? And they were just waiting
for an opportune time

to say, well tell
me your background, tell me why you're on
this team or tell me. And that could make
you, early on it

made me want to draw
back a little bit. And it took me a
while to figure out. It makes you afraid you'll
say something stupid

and that people will
remember it forever. But then it took me
a while to conclude that but hey yeah you may say
something-- and I'd sit there

and people would say something,
and I'd say, you know, I thought of that five minutes
ago but I didn't say anything. And after a while,
I began to say

you know I could
say something smart and they'll remember that too. So it's not just that I
have nothing but downsides,

you've also got upsides. And so if you do say
something that's insightful, something that adds
value, then you

begin to build a
reputation for yourself and people begin to
see you differently. But it took me--
and what made me do it is one of the partners
sat down with me and said,

you're to quiet, you
don't say enough. I think you've got things
that you don't bring out. And what I have
noticed over the years

and I think it's better
today than it was. But sometimes I think
things have changed, sometimes I wonder
if they've changed

as much as I think they have. But you will get people who will
be a little reluctant to tell

an African-American, to give
them straight advice, for fear they don't want to hear it
for fear that they'll quit. Or for fear that I'll
say well this person

had an African-American
worker and they drove him out of the company. So therefore they'll kind of
sugarcoat what they tell you.

And if you're not
hearing it, you know what'll happen
is you'll look at the people in the company
who are your peers, people that came in when you did.

And if you see
that they're moving ahead faster than you
are, then your conclusion, well, I think it's racism. Well, sometimes it is
and sometimes it's not.

And I go back again
to my thing in Texas. You know, my wife always worried
I was going to be mistreated.

And we're kind of the
opposite in that respect. There were problems
that I tended not to see and she saw every
problem that there was.

And so things that could appear
to be racism maybe were not.

And I saw in
retrospect, that the guy who was controller
before I took the job, was not very good at it. He was technically
very good, but there

are a lot of other
things that he didn't do that were
very well that I brought a whole different
perspective to the job.

Yes? You mentioned about
the technical things that the controller
did that were well,

but that's necessary
for the job. So my question is
what qualities did

you exude that help
distinguish you from you peers, how does the importance
of those qualities change as you move from
the entry level positions

to the c-suite? You know, within Medtronic we
have an organization called

the FLDS, the Finance
Leadership Development Council, and what we do is we tell-- in the old days you'd come
into a company and if you were,

you could have all the
technical required expertise, then that's what
got you to the top.

Today, that that's
not true anymore. You've got to partner
with the business. When I joined Medtronic
the guy who was controller,

I ended up having to terminate. And the reason for that
was he would say to people, you can't do that because
the rules say this.

And you can't do that. And I would say to him that's
not how you deal with people. You've got to say
to them, what is it

you're trying to get done? And then you work from there. And the guy that I replaced him
with, that's how he functioned.

Then you get to the point
where if he would say, well you can't do that, people
didn't question it anymore. They would know that
that was an honest view.

But he would say you
can't do that, but tell me what you want to get done. Let's figure out what we can do. And so it's again, it's
working with people

to get things done, which
will differentiate you. And so what we did is
we laid out for people

three phases in your
career, the early phase being technical knowledge. The second phase being
to work with people

who can make change. And the third phase being
able to lead change.

And what I told Professor
Foley's class today is if you look at CFOs
today, what they do

is so much the same
as what a CEO does. For example, when I talk
about one of the things

I did in Texas, when I got
the call from Dick Grasso, we didn't have an investor
relations organization.

And I had no idea what
investor relations did or how it should do it. So I had to learn
what is the buy side?

What is the sell side? How do you work with
portfolio managers? How do you work with
the securities analysts? And you know, you work
through all of that.

And if you're
really strategic you can learn so much from other
people if you ask questions. You can't come in
saying I know it all.

You've got to come in and
saying, like let's focus on this. And you've got to know where
you're trying to get to.

Yes? I noticed that you mentioned
your wife a couple of times and it seems like that you
also have a very rewarding work

career as well. Could you maybe speak to how
you balance that work and family life?

I think today younger people
are doing it better than I did. My son he lives in New
York and he has two boys.

And he has decided
that he is going to raise his boys in
the city, so he doesn't have all his long commute.

So when I worked for Citibank I
lived in the town of Hartsdale,

near White Plains. And I commuted every day. I know people who commuted
three hours a day. Now what I did for the work
balance was not all that easy.

Whenever I was in town
I always made a point, with our children, to give
them baths every night

and to read books to them. And I didn't, over
the weekends, learn to play golf or
anything because I didn't want to be gone all
day Saturday, all day Sunday.

And so they were pretty much,
I won't say totally mine, but a lot mine on the weekends.

But there's a downside to that. I mean, I had a job to do. And there were times
that I'd be under stress,

but I always did the
baths and the books. If that meant I got up at
3 o'clock the next morning to work, that's what I did.

So I ended up being
sleep deprived and at times I'd sit
in a chair and go to sleep the minute I sat down.

But you know you got to
work it out some way. Now I like what my son is doing. Where he's saying, I'm not
going to do all that commuting.

I'm going to live in the city. I'm going to raise my boys where
I can get home at a decent hour and see them every day.

It's not easy. And the other thing I would
say I learned from my dad

that's been with
me my whole life, he was one where he
sat me down as a-- I used to think he was a mean
person when I was a young kid.

And he sat me down as a
young person and he said, I want to tell you something. I have a job and you have a job. He said, you can't do
your job unless you

know what your job is. And I want to tell you, your
job is good citizenship grades and good academic grades. So if I'd come home and
I'd say, well this grade

wasn't what it should be or
that, I don't want to hear it. He said, you figure it out. And I never could
understand why he didn't

want to hear what I had to say. But then I fast
forward when we'd have to do these
road shows or we'd have to go out meeting
with investors.

And we always would
have three speakers. A CEO would be a speaker. The chief operating
officer would be one and I would be one.

And I typically had
the most pressure because the CEO would
say, he'd get up and talk in broad terms about strategy.

And then he'd say, well
any detailed questions, Bob will answer those. And the people you're meeting
with are financial people.

So I was always under the gun. And he'd come and say, well,
Bob are you ready to go? My answer was always the
same, do I have a choice?

And it was my job to be
ready and I had to do it.
